extending structs breaks programs embedding this struct into other structures (unlikely) and cython checks the size of these types and complains if they are different than what the program was built with, thats just an annoyance but one that comes up very often.

I haven't finished my ufunc patch yet, though it goes along the lines that njsmith suggested, keep the current structure and internally use a larger one. Additionally it might be interesting to mangle the public part in the development version to trigger failures for people that use the internals. For release the mangling can be reverted.

I hope no-one is embedding this struct into a larger one, b/c that's going
to be broken no matter what. I guess they might be able to get away with it
ATM because dtypes don't actually support GC traversal, but this is a bug
-- dtypes can participate in reference loops! (for example
dtype->subarray->base is a pointer to a dtype). And any type supporting GC
_must_ have all instances allocated via PyObject_GC_New, b/c this allocates
some extra memory at a known offset where the GC will scribble bookkeeping
information during its traversal. If you try to stick a GC-supporting type
into another struct or something anything like that, then the GC will end
up scribbling on random memory.

So I'm not too worried about breaking code that does that. It'll be broken
sooner or later regardless.

And I concur that the cython thing is just an annoyance. Probably we should
ask them to get rid of it.

I don't recall any reports of brokenness after the 1.7 release, which was
the last time we increased the size of dtype instances.

We should talk more about dtype rejiggering but probably this is not the
right thread for that discussion :-)

there is also the issue that users can create and fill their own dtype structures, by extending it the new fields are uninitialized and in this case would cause dtypes to have random hashes.
This problem can't be avoided, but if we do it we might as well do it properly by eliminating this problem for all future additions.

I was bit by that when adding frozen dimensions to ufuncs: the ufunc struct is initialized on its own by `np.frompyfunc` and the extra array I had added there was never allocated, leading to nasty crashes in the tests.

PyArray_DescrNew to do so? Or even if not I don't think there's any legal
way to allocate a PyObject that doesn't at least zero-initialize all the
fields. If we're worried we could make the "uninitialized" value here be
zero.
